text: DALI China åÛåÓ A typical morning for Lin Liya a native of Shanghai transplanted to this ancient town in southwest China goes like this: See her 3-year-old son off to school near the mountains; go for a half-hour run on the shores of Erhai Lake; and browse the local market for fresh vegetables and meat.         She finished her run one morning beneath cloudless blue skies and sat down with a visitor from Beijing in the lakeside boutique hotel started by her and her husband.         åÛåÏI think luxury is sunshine good air and good wateråÛå she said. åÛåÏBut in the big city you canåÛåªt get those things.åÛå         More than two years ago Ms. Lin 34 and her husband gave up comfortable careers in the booming southern city of Guangzhou åÛåÓ she at  a Norwegian risk management company  he at an advertising firm that he had founded åÛåÓ to join the growing number of urbanites who have decamped to rural China. One resident here calls them åÛåÏenvironmental refugeesåÛå or åÛåÏenvironmental immigrants.åÛå         At a time when hundreds of millions of Chinese many poor farmers are  leaving their country homesteads  to find work and tap into the energy of ChinaåÛåªs dynamic cities a small number of urban dwellers have decided to make a reverse migration. Their change in lifestyle speaks volumes about anxieties over pollution traffic living costs property values and the general stress found in ChinaåÛåªs biggest coastal metropolises.         Take  air quality : Levels of fine particulate matter in some Chinese cities reach  40 times  the recommended exposure limit set by the World Health Organization. This month an official Chinese news report said an 8-year-old  girl  near Shanghai was hospitalized with lung cancer the youngest such victim in China. Her doctor blamed air pollution.         The urban refugees come from all walks of life åÛåÓ businesspeople and artists teachers and chefs åÛåÓ though there is no reliable estimate of their numbers. They have staked out greener lives in small enclaves from central Anhui Province to remote Tibet. Many are Chinese bobos or bourgeois bohemians and they say that besides escaping pollution and filth they want to be unshackled from the material drives of the cities åÛåÓ what Ms. Lin derided as a focus on åÛåÏwhat youåÛåªre wearing where youåÛåªre eating comparing yourself with others.åÛå         The town of Dali in Yunnan Province nestled between a wall of 13000-foot mountains and one of ChinaåÛåªs largest freshwater lakes is a popular destination. Increasingly the indigenous ethnic Bai people of the area are leasing their village homes to ethnic Han the dominant group in China who turn up with suitcases and backpacks. They come with one-way tickets from places like Beijing Shanghai Guangzhou and Shenzhen all of which have roaring economies but also populations of 15 million people or more.         On Internet forums the new arrivals to Dali discuss how to rent a house where to shop how to make a living and what schools are best for their children. Their presence is everywhere in the cobblestone streets of the old town. They run cafes hotels and bookstores and the younger ones sit on the streets selling trinkets from blankets.         Some become farmers here and some spend their days home schooling their children. Their presence has transformed Dali and surrounding villages into a cross between Provence and Haight-Ashbury.         One magnet is the village of Shuanglang which became a draw after the famous Yunnan natives Yang Liping a dancer and Zhao Qing an artist built homes there. As at other lakeside villages the immigrants some with immense wealth live near fishermen and farmers.         åÛåÏAll kinds of people come here with different dreamsåÛå said Ye Yongqing 55 an ethnic Bai artist from the region who has lived mostly in cities including London but bought a home here five years ago. åÛåÏSome people imagine this place as Greece or Italy or Bali.åÛå         åÛåÏDali is one of the few places in China that still has a close tie to the earthåÛå he added sitting in front of a table of squashes in his garden courtyard. åÛåÏA lot of villages in China have become empty shells. Dali is a survivor of this phenomenon.åÛå         Ms. Lin said she first fell in love with Dali when she came as a backpacker in 2006. She returned twice before moving here. In 2010 on the third visit she and her husband whom she had met trekking in Yunnan looked for land to lease to build a hotel on Erhai Lake. It has not all been easy going Ms. Lin said citing negotiations and misunderstandings with local officials villagers and employees.         åÛåÏWe just wanted to switch to a different lifeåÛå said Ms. Lin who had lived in Shanghai as well as Guangzhou. åÛåÏMy friends in Shanghai are struggling there åÛåÓ not only in their work but also just to live. The prices are too high even higher than in Europe. They become crazy go mad.åÛå         Ms. Lin moved here less than two years after giving birth to a son. åÛåÏItåÛåªs good for the baby because itåÛåªs like my motheråÛåªs childhoodåÛå she said. åÛåÏMy motheråÛåªs childhood in Shanghai åÛåÓ the air was still clean you could see blue skies there was clean water.åÛå         That is a common refrain among parents here. One afternoon four mothers all urban refugees sat outside a bookstore cafe SongåÛåªs Nest practicing English with one another. åÛåÏThe one thing we all have in common is we moved here to raise our children in a good environmentåÛå one woman said.         The bookshopåÛåªs owner Song Yan moved here this year and translates books by an Indian philosopher popular with Chinese spiritual seekers. One night she and another translator and urban refugee Zheng Yuantao 33 talked over dinner about their moves.         åÛåÏIåÛåªve never felt so free in my lifeåÛå Mr. Zheng said. åÛåÏI grew up as a city boy and I never realized how much I like living close to nature.åÛå         From the nearby lakeside village of Caicun Huang Xiaoling a photographer flies back to Beijing to shoot portraits and events for clients. She had once lived in a courtyard home in the Chinese capital but fled in September with her 3-year-old son and husband an American who works remotely as a technology director for a New York publishing company.         åÛåÏIåÛåªm still productive even though I donåÛåªt go into an officeåÛå she said. åÛåÏI donåÛåªt know if itåÛåªs the weather and the environment or just me feeling that åÛå÷Oh I got out of the cave that I wanted to escape.åÛåªÌâåÊåÛå

Poor George Bailey. As if he werenåÛåªt already teetering on the edge a  Christmas  Eve visit to a bar is no help to Jimmy StewartåÛåªs desperate protagonist in åÛåÏItåÛåªs a Wonderful Life.åÛå Just before resolving to end it all he gets hammered at the hands of  one of the least agreeable barmen on film  in a bar where even an angel gets no respect.         Then thereåÛåªs Jack LemmonåÛåªs hapless C. C. Baxter in åÛåÏThe ApartmentåÛå who is forced out of his lodgings on Christmas so his no-good boss can rendezvous there with his mistress leaving Baxter with no choice but to repair to a saloon. There he finds  a great thrum of festivity  but the merriment as conceived by the brilliantly cynical Billy Wilder is hollow at its core. Baxter chain-smokes and drinks martini after martini fraternizing miserably with a fellowship of the forlorn.         The message from these Hollywood classics is clear: a bar is no place to be at Christmas. ItåÛåªs a last resort the bottom of the barrel a holiday holding pen for losers and lowlifes the unloved and unlucky.         IåÛåªve been there.         IåÛåªve never had it as bad as Bailey or Baxter but I wasnåÛåªt exactly in a jolly mood the first time I spent a good portion of my holiday in a bar. I think it was the winter of my junior year in college. I came home to New York to celebrate with my family and got into a screaming match with my mother at the dinner table on Christmas Day.         So I did what any self-respecting angst-ridden young person would do: I excused myself from the table took a walk had a good sulk ate some Chinese food saw a movie and as my last stop before returning home hit a bar. No place special. Nowhere I had been before.         But instead of finding despair in there I encountered a measure of cheer and comfort that had eluded me at home at least that year. I had a whiskey and a few beers and I enjoyed a nice chat with a friendly bartender a couple of customers who had to work most of the day and another who was newish to New York.         I felt much better. I think we all did.         It turns out that around the holidays bars do exactly what they are always supposed to do: provide a place to blow off steam far from the demands of home or office. This season may be the most treasured time to spend with family but it can also foment discord. Expectations are high. Our homes are supposed to be festively decked out. Our cooking should be perfectly timed and unimpeachably delicious.         With the holidays come pressure whether we spend them with our families or not. And the bar is one place that can relieve that pressure.         Like those whom I met during college break many of the people youåÛåªll find at bars during the holidays are trying to relax after a workday or are new to town. But itåÛåªs not a default for everyone; for some of us itåÛåªs a choice.         A bar holiday may be tinged with melancholy but itåÛåªs a sweet sort of melancholy. (Its tone is captured perfectly IåÛåªm compelled to say in  John Denver and Rowlf the DogåÛåªs rendition of åÛåÏHave Yourself A Merry Little ChristmasåÛå  on the åÛåÏJohn Denver and the Muppets: A Christmas TogetheråÛå TV special in 1979.)         I am not alone in my view that a bar can be a source of holiday comfort. åÛåÏI donåÛåªt know if itåÛåªs anything specialåÛå the playwright Peter Gil-Sheridan said of Christmas at FlanneryåÛåªs Bar an Irish dive on West 14th Street åÛåÏbut it is to me.åÛå         Mr. Gil-Sheridan found the bar years ago when he was cat-sitting for a friend in the neighborhood. That friend later moved but Mr. Gil-Sheridan who lives in Brooklyn still returns almost every Christmas to FlanneryåÛåªs where the management serves a free turkey feast. åÛåÏI love that they unceremoniously put out some turkey and potatoes and stuffing and gravyåÛå he said. åÛåÏThereåÛåªs no announcement. ItåÛåªs just there in the back because itåÛåªs Christmas so of course thereåÛåªs some turkey around. And you kind of discover it and think åÛå÷Yeah IåÛåªll have some of that.åÛåªÌâåÊåÛå         Last year Mr. Gil-Sheridan and his partner had to fly to London on Christmas but they considered taking a night flight so they could spend the day at FlanneryåÛåªs. åÛåÏIn the end we decided against it but I missed itåÛå he said.         There are others whose bar Christmases have more closely resembled George BaileyåÛåªs. The British-born author and bartender Gary Regan recalled Christmas in 1975 his first in New York City. He was manning the bar at DrakeåÛåªs Drum an Upper East Side establishment he describes as åÛåÏa neighborhood joint that attracted rugby players and their groupiesåÛå as well as lawyers plumbers and artists.         Mr. Regan didnåÛåªt relish the idea of working on Christmas but his boss assured him the tips would make it worthwhile. Nearly 40 years later he remembers this as the worst bar shift of his life. Each customer was surlier than the last. åÛåÏThere was a damned good reason nobody had invited them anywhereåÛå he said         IåÛåªve spent Christmas on the working side of a bar too at  South  in South Park Slope Brooklyn. Last year Christmas fell on a Tuesday the day of my usual shift. I opened the bar at 5 p.m. The first hour was dead and foot traffic on Fifth Avenue was thin. åÛåÏWhy am I doing this?åÛå I wondered bracing myself for a lonely night.         But business picked up around 6 when regulars returned from early family dinners badly wanting drinks sans relatives. And knowing that I was working for the holiday several friends turned up to surprise me not a few bearing cookies and leftover pie and other gifts. Some sang along as my favorite holiday playlist issued from the speakers (including Rowlf and John Denver naturally). I lit some extra candles and soon enough you could feel some genuine Christmas cheer warming the room like the hot toddies warming my customers.         Even if thereåÛåªs no room at the inn thereåÛåªs plenty at the pub.          COMFORT AND JOY:  A sampling of bars open on Christmas.          Commonwealth   This place known for things like its killer jukebox and Kentucky Derby Day party will open at 8 p.m. on  Christmas . Expect psychedelic holiday decorations and indie-rock Christmas anthems.  497 Fifth Avenue (12th Street) Park Slope Brooklyn.    The Dead Rabbit   The upstairs parlor will be closed at one of New YorkåÛåªs great cocktail destinations but the homey downstairs taproom will open at 5 p.m. offering delights like Irish coffee hot whiskey punch and a special eggnog until it runs out.  30 Water Street (Broad Street).    Le ChÌÄå©ile   This Irish pub in Washington Heights will open at 11 a.m. Starting at 1 p.m. it will serve a prix fixe traditional Irish Christmas dinner including roast turkey and baked ham.  839 West 181st Street.    LuluåÛåªs   ItåÛåªll be a family affair at this cozy local starting at 8 p.m. with Patsy Monteleone playing Christmas tunes on the ukulele and Ani mixing holiday cocktails named after relatives like the Cousin Vince.          113 Franklin Street Greenpoint Brooklyn.    Tom and JerryåÛåªs    This downtown stalwart will open at 4 p.m. On the menu: hot apple cider with bourbon and spice-laced åÛåÏwinter martinis.åÛå  288 Elizabeth Street (East Houston Street).

We drew a deep breath before entering the tunnel. The garbage strewn around the entrance was about as inviting as the prospect of walking nearly a mile under one of  Paris åÛåªs most famous parks not knowing what or whom to expect. We were in the heart of the city but completely removed from it.         But with four of us there was safety in numbers and so we set out into the darkness to explore one of the cityåÛåªs more hidden treasures: the Petite Ceinture. Forget the Catacombes or the ÌÄåägouts; impressive as ParisåÛåªs underground bone repository (the former) and sewers (the latter) are the abandoned  rail line encircling the city  offers urban hikers a new perspective.         A section of the line in the 16th Arrondissement was opened to the public as a nature trail in 2008 and another in the 15th Arrondissement was opened this summer; there is also a short path in the 12th. The Jardin de la Rue du Colonel ManhÌÄå¬s is a verdant narrow park in the 17th Arrondissement that runs parallel to the railway.         As nice as those are we wanted to see more of the Petite Ceinture and that meant exploring sections that have not been repurposed and that are not necessarily easy to hike. It is officially forbidden to walk the tracks with high fencing lining the entire beltway (ceinture means åÛåÏbeltåÛå in French) but for the most part the authorities look the other way. As Richard Prost who has lived in areas neighboring the tracks for most his life and  has made a documentary  on the subject put it: åÛåÏIf youåÛåªre a polite hiker the cops will simply ask you to leave.åÛå On a pleasant weekend dozens of intrepid Parisians can be found walking the rails.         Knowing where you can get in and out of the Petite Ceinture is critical. In most places the railway is sunken åÛåÓ the tracks are below street level which can feel like being in the bottom of a valley. Along the way there are tunnels trestles and elevated sections. We figured a good place to start was the Jardins du Ruisseau (Porte de Clignancourt MÌÄå©tro stop) near the MarchÌÄå© aux Puces on the northern edge of Paris. The community garden in the 18th Arrondissement has taken up residence along the north bank of the tracks and includes a chicken coop beehives and about three dozen plots bursting with a variety of vegetables and flowers. It is a great place to unwind on a warm afternoon but as it turns out a bad place to try to get onto the tracks. So we continued until we found a breach in the fence and started on our way.         Much of the 18th Arrondissement seemed a concrete wasteland of industrial infrastructure as we walked alone out of breath not so much from exertion but out of apprehension over what lay ahead and because we knew an easy exit would be all but impossible. The 33 kilometers (20 miles) of tracks surrounded Paris when they were built in the mid-19th century connecting passengers and freight with the cityåÛåªs major train stations. The Paris MÌÄå©tro gradually replaced the Petite Ceinture and in 1934 commuter service virtually ended. Freight trains continued to use the network until 1993.         Our urban hiking was tough going: The weeds were one reason; having to walk on the wooden ties or the loose rock between them was another. At a spot with chest-high overgrowth we crossed paths with our first taggeurs or graffiti artists of the day. We uttered a quick bonjour before scuttling off.         A massive heap of concrete beckoned. We were walking through what is listed on maps as a warehouse parking garage and a subway repair facility.         As we approached the Canal de låÛåªOurcq and the Parc de la Villette it didnåÛåªt help our anxiety levels to recall that until 1974 this was the site of the slaughterhouses of Paris åÛåÓ but it did beat the åÛåÏMad MaxåÛå zone we had just bushwhacked through. Confronted by a construction site and an active suburban train line we were forced to climb down from the tracks to cross the canal by a regular pedestrian bridge. While searching for a way back up we discovered a community of artists working in studios wedged between the arches that support this elevated section of track.         Flowers plants and bright artistic creations decorate the entrances to their vaulted workplaces. åÛåÏWeåÛåªve carved ourselves into the Petite CeintureåÛå Sylviane Borie said with a laugh. She is part of a loose collective of sculptors rap musicians and painters who have åÛåÏcreated links with the community and camaraderie amongst artistsåÛå she continued åÛåÏbut our voice isnåÛåªt being heard.åÛå Like the Petite Ceinture the collective is in legal no manåÛåªs land and is facing eviction.         Peeling back a sheet-metal partition that was blocking access to another construction site we ascended a long ramp that led up to a fence separating the site from the tracks. We found an opening in the fence and after hoisting ourselves over it we were back on the tracks. We soon realized we were above the Paris that we had seen a thousand times from ground level. From our elevated perspective we could see the Parisians on the way to their Sunday market waiting for the bus and children playing.

I finally understand how pregnant women feel when others bombard them with birthing horror stories because I recently attempted the home-improvement equivalent of childbirth: refinishing wood floors.         I heard a story of a drum sander running off a second-story deck a runaway buffer destroying a wall and of course many ruined floors.         åÛåÏNever againåÛå was the most common refrain.         ItåÛåªs hard to square such reactions with online tutorials produced in the can-do spirit of home improvement salesmanship. In one such video a woman strips her moribund kitchen floor without so much as a hint of sweat or effort.         Much like childbirth.         My floor project scored a solid 85 on the torture scale and I had help from three specialists: James Toal owner of Floors of Distinction in Connecticut; Phil Sanchez national account manager for Bona a manufacturer of cleaners and finishes for wood floors; and Charles Peterson a floor builder and author of åÛåÏA Complete Guide to Layout Installation & Finishing Wood FlooringåÛå (Taunton 2010). You can save thousands of dollars by doing the job yourself they said but not everyone can or should.         The project involves heavy machinery and power tools with vast destructive potential and procedural land mines that can mar the final product. And even when rookies navigate those obstacles they seldom achieve professional results.         So if your preholiday ambitions include taking a flyer on floor refinishing burn your plans. Then when you have a few days off from work and no party-organizing pressure start by dialing down your expectations.         åÛåÏYou wonåÛåªt do a good job with thisåÛå Mr. Peterson said. åÛåÏForgive me but not a chance.åÛå         While itåÛåªs easy to do a good job of coating a floor with a new finish taking the old finish off is mercilessly hard. Mr. Toal pointed out that many builders employ in-house specialists for electrical work plumbing and other arcane functions.         åÛåÏBut not sanding floorsåÛå he said. åÛåÏThey donåÛåªt want anything to do with it.åÛå         Neither did I but I lacked the budget to hire professionals for my entire floor and I couldnåÛåªt leave it as it was. A last-minute holiday refreshing a few years ago did not last long and the floors had reached a new level of nastiness since.         Where to begin?         On your knees my panelists said.         Remove a heating register or even a short strip of wood to make sure the floor is thick enough to sand. You need a minimum of one-eighth of an inch of wood above the tongue of the board Mr. Peterson said.         Even if you end up doing the floors yourself this might be a good time to call for a professional consultation. Mr. Toal said that some wood floor specialists will visit a home or offer phone-based guidance to people who are planning a do-it-yourself refinish. That counsel he said can extend to weekend or evening phone calls.         It may take several phone calls to find such a contractor but for $50 or $75 this sort of help can be a godsend.         Seek an estimate while youåÛåªre at it and compare it with your list of supplies and rental needs. Mine included a drum sander ($45 daily) orbit sander ($65 daily) buffer/grinder ($40 daily) and a van to haul equipment ($30 daily).         I also bought a Shop-Vac ($70) a small hand sander ($30) a scraper good kneepads plastic sheeting painteråÛåªs tape a pry bar wood filler and putty knife a nail set for burying nails tack cloth and paint pads.         Finally I invested in a half-face respirator ($30 from 3M) because cheaper masks offer poor protection against toxic wood dust. Total spent on supplies rental fees excluded: $425.         By comparison Mr. Peterson said reputable contractors will charge roughly $3 per square foot.         Spend an hour or two researching the inventory at nearby rental shops so you can minimize wasted trips. Then empty your rooms and your schedule. I allotted a day for clearing a day for prep and gathering supplies a day for sanding and a day for applying finish.

åÛåÏI have the chance to go to Japan for a yearåÛå I told my boyfriend Randy.         åÛåÏBut I canåÛåªt come with youåÛå he said.         I wanted to pack him up and take him along but his life and work were in New York so we promised to visit each other during my one-year teaching contract and switched to cheap phone plans. We were going to be a progressive couple who could support each other in pursuing our dreams strong enough to let each other thrive apart.         We had met three years earlier when I was a 22-year-old English major just out of college living in Greenwich Village. He was standing by me in a deli line tall with blond spiky hair like Bart Simpson.         åÛåÏHope youåÛåªre not stuck with just hundredsåÛå he said to me pointing to a homemade åÛåÏNo Change for $100åÛå sign taped on the counter.         We talked until chairs were being stacked mops were moving and we had to be kicked out. We discovered we both had a band of freckles on our upper left arms that looked like the Big Dipper. Later he would hold me with that arm as we melded into one constellation on the futon in my tiny apartment.         Randy was my first serious relationship. It was 2001. He was the one I rushed to find when the twin towers fell when the smoke billowed and rose. Life was uncertain but Randy felt solid.         For three years we hung out going to his shows with his group of ragtag rocker friends. When our leases expired we moved in together. Weekends were spent at his gigs with him firmly in the spotlight.         But when I saw the newspaper ad for teaching English in Japan it struck like a gong. I had been obsessed with Japan since childhood had studied Zen and kanji in college. I needed to explore to claim my own spotlight for a while.         Yet on the plane across the Pacific I watched several old Japanese women do calisthenics near the emergency exit and I suddenly couldnåÛåªt breathe. It hit me: I was going halfway around the world alone. I would be living by myself in Osaka teaching English in a school in the back of a mall. And I knew no one there. Except Mika.         Mika and I became pen pals when I was 7 and her neighbor visited my familyåÛåªs upstate farm. She left with my address and a picture of me with red hair. Two months later I received a letter.         åÛåÏHelloåÛå it read. åÛåÏMy name is Mika.åÛå In her photo she wore long dark braids and a shirt with the English alphabet.         Mika and I wrote letters for 15 years. When I moved to Manhattan I sent her a map of the island with a gold star downtown. åÛåÏI am hereåÛå I wrote.         When I fell for Randy I told Mika how his James Taylor voice serenaded me while he made smooshed grilled cheese and tomato soup in our small kitchen. I described walking along streets with my hand in his oversize pockets.         Now I was moving to her island.         Training with American expats in central Osaka I felt overwhelmed and shy. The company housed me in a studio that looked from the outside like a washing machine. Every morning I woke to fliers for teenage pornography slid under my door like delivery menus. I rode the train to work aware of the other passengers staring at my bright red hair. I began wearing black hats to cover it.         Japan was beautiful but isolating. On my pink cellphone I called Randy daily. When I got his voice mail repeatedly I rationalized: the time difference. Sometimes I called just to hear his recording.         One weekend I took the bullet train past Mount Fuji to meet Mika.         åÛåÏKonnichiwa!åÛå she exclaimed greeting me at the door. I stared at my longtime friend her hair cut short her eyes farther apart in person. We gave each other a silent hug. I knew this girl so deeply yet we could barely communicate. My spoken Japanese boiled down to three phrases: åÛåÏNo fish flakes pleaseåÛå åÛåÏThank youåÛå and åÛåÏWhere is the bathroom?åÛå Mika wrote better English than she spoke.         We sat on tatami mats and smiled at each other. We ate noodley soups and fresh tofu. Mika was dating a businessman. In a photo I pointed to RandyåÛåªs light blue eyes.         After dinner Mika brought out an envelope with all my letters. In my happy 10-year-oldåÛåªs script IåÛåªd written: åÛåÏDear Mika I have a dog too!åÛå How many tiny details weåÛåªd shared.         Back in my washing machine apartment I could get free Wi-Fi if I placed my laptop on the windowsill overlooking clotheslines. When Randy and I exchanged instant messages I felt anchored.

Even as Americans struggle with the changes required by health care reform  an international survey  released last week by the Commonwealth Fund a research organization shows why change is so necessary.         The report found that by virtually all measures of cost access to care and ease of dealing with insurance problems Americans fared poorly compared with people in other advanced countries. The survey covered 20000 adults in the United States and 10 other industrial nations åÛåÓ Australia Canada France Germany the Netherlands New Zealand Norway Sweden Switzerland and Britain all of which put in place universal or near-universal health coverage decades ago. The United States spends far more than any of these countries on a per capita basis and as a percent of the national economy.         For that it gets meager results. Some 37 percent of American adults went without recommended care did not see a doctor when sick or failed to fill prescriptions in the past year because of costs compared with 4 percent in Britain and 6 percent in Sweden. Nearly a quarter of American adults could not pay medical bills or had serious problems paying them compared with less than 13 percent in France and 7 percent or less in five other countries. Even Americans who were insured for the entire year were more likely than adults abroad to forgo care because of costs an indication of how skimpy some insurance policies are.         When Americans got sick they had to wait longer than people in most of the other countries to get help. Fewer than half were able to get same-day or next-day appointments with a doctor or nurse; one in four had to wait six days or longer. (Only Canada fared worse on both counts.) But Americans got quicker access to specialists than adults in all but two other countries.         The complexity of the American insurance system is also an issue. Some 32 percent of consumers spent a lot of time on insurance paperwork or in disputes with their insurer over denials of payment for services they thought were covered.         The Affordable Care Act was created to address these problems by covering tens of millions of uninsured people and providing subsidies to help many of them pay for policies; by setting limits on the out-of-pocket costs that patients must bear; and by requiring that all policies cover specified benefits.         Americans are understandably frustrated with the Obama administrationåÛåªs failure to produce a functioning website. President ObamaåÛåªs erroneous statements that all people who like their current insurance policies can keep them åÛåÓ not true for many people buying insurance in the individual market åÛåÓ has added to anger and misunderstanding. The reform law however imperfect is needed to bring the dysfunctional American health care system up to levels already achieved in other advanced nations.

It takes only a moment to step over the line especially when no one knows exactly where the line is. In my case it started with a visit from my old friend the activist. The activist became my patient back in the mid-1990s when H.I.V. was slowly morphing into a treatable disease. He was young then with a mop of dark curls ‰ÛÓ excitable suspicious and frantic about his health. He was convinced the new drugs were pure synthetic poison a profiteering scam by the government and Big Pharma. He was also feeling sick enough that he thought he might just give them a try. He lurched back and forth between these two incompatible positions once or twice a month dragging me and my prescription pad behind him in a flurry of abandoned amber plastic bottles. Eventually though good sense kicked in and he had to admit that on meds he felt a lot better than otherwise. He managed to retain his contempt for the system while regularly filling his prescriptions. I no longer winced at his name on my schedule. And now it is suddenly decades later his H.I.V. has long been perfectly controlled and he is still fomenting revolution. He used to march and holler; now he works social media with a miserable old desktop computer that keeps breaking down. As it happens about a week before one of our infrequent appointments ‰ÛÓ he barely needs me any more ‰ÛÓ I had treated myself to a brand new laptop sending an old perfectly good model into the back of the closet. Of course I wiped its hard drive clean and gave it to him ‰ÛÓ for he is my old friend. But (also of course) we met furtively in a back corridor and I carefully concealed the contraband in a nest of old grocery bags ‰ÛÓ for he is my patient and gifts to patients ‰Û_well we don‰Ûªt usually do that. Once again apparently we were dealing with two incompatible positions. Everyone knows that professional boundaries guide all medical activity in hospital office and clinic. But aside from indisputable sexual and financial depredations no one agrees exactly where these boundaries lie. Kindness to friend and duty to patient: Are they one and the same? Or separated by a barbed-wire fence? Opinion is all over the map. At one extreme is the position probably best articulated by one of medicine‰Ûªs great clinician-scientists Dr. Donald Seldin of the University of Texas. In a 1981 talk to an audience of physicians Dr. Seldin deplored ‰ÛÏa tendency to construe all sorts of human problems as medical problems‰Û and thus within doctors‰Ûª duty and purview to fix. If it isn‰Ûªt ‰ÛÏrelief of pain prevention of disability and postponement of death‰Û Dr. Seldin said why then doctor leave it alone! He got a  standing ovation . In the opposite corner stands Dr. Gordon Schiff of Harvard‰Ûªs Brigham and Women‰Ûªs Hospital who was issued an official reprimand a few years ago for egregious boundary crossing. The incident that it set it off: Dr. Schiff (now 63 an experienced senior clinician) had tangled with an insurer on the phone for two hours before he gave up and handed an impoverished patient $30 to pay for her pain pills. A resident observed the transaction and turned him in. But Dr. Schiff is a proud repeat offender whose past infractions include helping patients get jobs giving them jobs himself offering them rides home extending the occasional dinner invitation and yes once handing over a computer. He was told physicians should stay away from ‰ÛÏrandom acts of kindness‰Û ‰ÛÓ an activity that may sound harmless but is quite distinct from the practice of medicine and has its risks. Patients might get too familiar expect too much. Dr. Schiff  published  a long rumination about the incident a few months ago (which he reported in an interview has elicited the email equivalent of a standing ovation). In it he considers whom exactly the sanctions against befriending patients are designed to protect. The patient in some instances he concludes but the doctor in far more. ‰ÛÏLet‰Ûªs not pretend we are imposing limits for patients rather than our own best interests.‰Û Dr. Schiff draws medicine‰Ûªs borders around a shared social agenda: doctors help the patient‰Ûªs health by helping the whole patient. Dr. Seldin‰Ûªs borders contain specific technical tasks. If you think too superficially about all of this you may begin to hear Dr. Seldin screeching like Ebenezer Scrooge: Are there no charities? Are there no social workers? But it‰Ûªs not quite that simple. I too handed out the odd $20 bill at work without thinking much about it until I didn‰Ûªt see one patient for almost a full year afterward ‰ÛÓ and she was a sick person who really needed care. What had happened? ‰ÛÏI couldn‰Ûªt come back without your money‰Û she said. So that was a random act of blindness on my part good evidence of the perils of the terrain and the need to think before each step. I think ‰ÛÓ I hope ‰ÛÓ the activist and I understand each other a little better than that. Dr. Abigail Zuger on the everyday ethical issues doctors face. All open questions åÈ Marathon half-marathon 10k and 5K training plans to get you race ready. How much do you know about the amazing things that go on in your gut? Test your knowledge of flu facts and trivia.

Maybe Godot never appears because everyone is mispronouncing his name.         More than 60 years after the debut of  åÛåÏWaiting for GodotåÛå  BeckettåÛåªs absurdist drama about two vagabonds anticipating a mysterious savior there is much disagreement among directors actors critics and scholars on how the name of that elusive title figure should be spoken.         åÛåÏGOD-ohåÛå with the accent on the first syllable is how åÛåÏit should be pronouncedåÛå said Sean Mathias the British director of  the latest a Broadway revival  of åÛåÏWaiting for GodotåÛå opening later this month at the Cort Theater.         åÛåÏIt has to be reallyåÛå he said. åÛåÏThereåÛåªs no other way to do it.åÛå         But the theater critic John Lahr said that rendering åÛåÏis too obviousåÛå for the playwright  Samuel Beckett  with its suggestion of the Almighty.         åÛåÏBeckett is more elusive and poetic and he wouldnåÛåªt hit it on the head like thatåÛå said Mr. Lahr a longtime contributor to The New Yorker who instead advocates for åÛåÏgod-OHåÛå with the accent on the second syllable.         Georges Borchardt a literary agent who represented Beckett and continues to represent his literary estate suggested even a third pronunciation was possible.         åÛåÏI myself have always pronounced it the French way with equal emphasis on both syllablesåÛå Mr. Borchardt said in an email.         Mr. Borchardt said he had consulted with Edward Beckett a nephew of the author who told him that his uncle pronounced it the same way and that Edward Beckett could not see åÛåÏwhy there should be a correct or incorrect way of pronouncing Godot.åÛå         åÛåÏAs the agents for the estateåÛå Mr. Borchardt continued åÛåÏwe do not insist on any particular pronunciation.åÛå         There seems to be nothing to be done to reconcile these competing camps and productions of åÛåÏGodotåÛå do what they will.  In a video recording  Peter Hall who directed the first British production in 1955 pronounces it GOD-oh.  An American television production  from 1961 starring Burgess Meredith and Zero Mostel uses åÛåÏgod-OH.åÛå Discussing his role in the 2009 Broadway production  Nathan Lane says  åÛåÏGOD-oh.åÛå         åÛåÏI donåÛåªt think there is a mathematical solution to this problemåÛå said Mark Nixon the director of the  Beckett International Foundation  at the University of Reading in England.         Dr. Nixon said he believed the name was correctly pronounced with a stressed first syllable. But he said åÛåÏI donåÛåªt feel strongly in the sense that I would correct somebody who said it differently.åÛå         Still he did not dismiss the Godot question as a trivial issue. åÛåÏNothingåÛåªs trivial when it comes to BeckettåÛå he said.         The debate would surely please Beckett an Irish author who originally wrote åÛåÏWaiting for GodotåÛå in French before translating it into English and whose work embraced ambiguity and resisted easy interpretation. As this Nobel laureate wrote åÛåÏno symbols where none intendedåÛå but he kept his intentions mysterious and seemed to leave symbols everywhere. The pronunciation of Godot like the name itself seems pregnant with meaning yet ambiguous.         One might think that BeckettåÛåªs own writing would plainly reveal his wishes but gosh no.         According to åÛåÏThe Theatrical Notebooks of Samuel BeckettåÛå (Grove Press) when åÛåÏWaiting for GodotåÛå was performed in the 1980s by the San Quentin Drama Workshop Beckett sought åÛåÏto counter the natural American tendency to stress the second syllableåÛå and asked his actors åÛåÏconsciously to pronounce it with the stress on the first syllable instead.åÛå         Dr. Nixon said that recordings of the authoråÛåªs voice are extremely rare åÛåÓ åÛåÏonly about four or four and a half are in existence.åÛå         åÛåÏIåÛåªve heard all of themåÛå Dr. Nixon said åÛåÏand on none of those recordings does he use the word Godot. So unfortunately thatåÛåªs not a route we can take.åÛå         The French-looking name Godot may seem to call for a French pronunciation. But in an English-language production speaking Godot without stressing either syllable åÛåÏwould be similar to saying åÛå÷PareeåÛåª for ParisåÛå explained the actor Adrian Dunbar an experienced Beckett performer.         åÛåÏAlthough not incorrectåÛå he said åÛåÏit does sound a little shall we say faux.åÛå         There is no definitive origin story for the name Godot either. It may be BeckettåÛåªs reference to the French bicyclist Roger Godeau or to French slang words for boots a pair of which feature prominently in the play.         Mr. Lahr rejected the interpretation that Godot was simply a stand-in for God an idea he said was too easily conjured up by the pronunciation GOD-oh.         When his father the actor Bert Lahr played Estragon in  the original American productions  of åÛåÏWaiting for GodotåÛå Mr. Lahr said åÛåÏgod-OHåÛå was used.         åÛåÏIt keeps it open-ended and more painful almost as if thereåÛåªs nothing out thereåÛå Mr. Lahr said. åÛåÏWhich there isnåÛåªt in BeckettåÛåªs vision.åÛå         And for American ears the GOD-oh pronunciation can sound affected and can take some getting used to.         Mr. Mathias whose production of åÛåÏWaiting for GodotåÛå was originally staged  in the West End of London  said that when it transferred to New York åÛåÏwe had to train everybodyåÛå to embrace this pronunciation.         åÛåÏCould you imagine the poor crew?åÛå Mr. Mathias asked cheekily. åÛåÏAnybody who says åÛå÷god-OHåÛåª I say åÛå÷Excuse me? WhatåÛåªs that? WeåÛåªre not doing that play.åÛåª Poor things.åÛå         Shane Baker who translated åÛåÏWaiting for GodotåÛå  into Yiddish  said that actors in this version of the play said åÛåÏgod-OHåÛå because åÛåÏthatåÛåªs how itåÛåªs known in America.åÛå         åÛåÏI was the translatoråÛå said Mr. Baker who also played Vladimir in the New Yiddish Rep production at the Castillo Theater in Manhattan. åÛåÏBut the producer and director wanted god-OH so there you have it.åÛå         åÛåÏWe did it wrongåÛå he said. åÛåÏLook I had other battles I had to fight.åÛå         Mr. Baker added that over the years åÛåÏWaiting for GodotåÛå had become part of åÛåÏthe peopleåÛåªs imagination.åÛå It has been paid tribute in films like åÛåÏWaiting for GuffmanåÛå and the subject of a åÛåÏSesame StreetåÛå parody  åÛåÏWaiting for Elmo.åÛå   Saying åÛåÏgod-OHåÛå he said has become part of the vernacular and it is too late to talk audiences out of it.         åÛåÏThe rest of the play is jarring enoughåÛå Mr. Baker said. åÛåÏWhy upset them?åÛå

ThereåÛåªs a good chance that a vast majority of musicians who have come up through this countryåÛåªs student orchestras and concert bands have stormed through the inexorable finale of ShostakovichåÛåªs Symphony No. 5. Far fewer musicians of any age will have played the famous conclusion in the manner that the conductor  Benjamin Zander  molded it during a concert by the  Boston Philharmonic Youth Orchestra  at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening.         Mr. Zander also an admired pedagogue and motivational speaker is renowned for coaxing professional-quality work from amateurs and for wringing fresh insights from even the most familiar works. Both characteristics surfaced during the New York debut of this ensemble established last year as an offshoot of Mr. ZanderåÛåªs admired Boston Philharmonic Orchestra. The members of the youth orchestra ages 12 to 21 play with a maturity and cohesion well beyond their years a point made in numerous  audio and video clips  on the ensembleåÛåªs web page.         In the Shostakovich especially the finale Mr. Zander is a stickler for the composeråÛåªs tempo markings and note values as indicative of the expressive intent. The movement starts at 88 to the eighth note mounts to a feverish 184 then retreats back to 92 åÛåÓ at which point notes double in length. Thus the ostensibly triumphal coda Mr. Zander explained before the performance is meant to sound beaten down and labored: points missed outright even in benchmark interpretations.         Here those qualities were enacted convincingly at the close of a brilliantly played fervently felt account enriched with silken strings robust brass and eloquent solos by the principal winds and the concertmaster Max Tan.         By then the orchestraåÛåªs acumen and poise had been firmly established in a precise exuberant rendition of VerdiåÛåªs overture to åÛåÏLa Forza del DestinoåÛå and two coruscating movements from Michael GandolfiåÛåªs åÛåÏGarden of Cosmic Speculation.åÛå  Christopher OåÛåªRiley  a former student of Mr. ZanderåÛåªs was the stylish soloist in a luscious account of RavelåÛåªs Piano Concerto in G with haunting work from Nicole Caligiuri on English horn in the Adagio.         Whoops whistles and flash bulbs at the end attested to an abundance of family and friends in the audience but the concert was one that any music lover would savor.

DETROIT åÛåÓ Kevyn D. Orr the man who must now revive Detroit commutes each week from Maryland to a cavernous old office building here that seems to dare him to succeed: the former headquarters of a company itself recently in bankruptcy that once sold more than half of AmericaåÛåªs cars åÛåÓ General Motors.         His office on the 14th floor is sparsely furnished but in the stack of papers on his desk he keeps a few photographs åÛåÓ of New York City at its financial low in the 1970s. Gritty streets that look he says like some of DetroitåÛåªs unlit forgotten neighborhoods today.         åÛåÏAnytime somebody says it canåÛåªt happen I whip those pictures out and say åÛå÷Oh donåÛåªt you bet against itåÛåªÌâåÊåÛå Mr. Orr said the other day not long after a federal judge allowed Detroit to become the  nationåÛåªs largest city ever to enter bankruptcy . åÛåÏLet me show you what can happen.åÛå         Mr. Orr 55 who has never run for political office finds himself in an extraordinary role. He holds power even more concentrated than that of the emergency control board that intervened when  New York City was teetering near bankruptcy  an  unelected lawyer chiefly responsible for the reinvention of a major American city  in decay. And thereåÛåªs a deadline åÛåÓ 10 months.         The assignment is enormous a peculiar mix of duties some stated and others not for a man who by all accounts had been leading a comfortable life as a bankruptcy lawyer. His new job? Urban planner numbers cruncher city spokesman negotiator politician good cop bad cop.         The job could not be more politically fraught. Mr. OrråÛåªs harshest critics call him a åÛåÏdictatoråÛå (his authority trumps that of the cityåÛåªs elected leaders) an åÛåÏUncle TomåÛå (he is black and was sent to run this mostly black city by a white governor) and a åÛåÏpension killeråÛå (he has said the  city can no longer afford the pensions  it promised retirees). But Mr. Orr who was a partner at the law firm Jones Day until his wife and a mentor helped talk him into taking the Detroit job seems unfazed by the storm around him. He is full of smiles and quips coolly pressing on.         åÛåÏIf we donåÛåªt do something to address the unfunded liability that we have the 700000 residents åÛåÓ some of them schoolchildren some of them sort of skinny dorky kids like I was who got beaten up every day at the bus stop by the toughs who have to walk home in the dark åÛåÓ donåÛåªt they deserve better services?åÛå said Mr. Orr who grew up in Florida and visited Detroit as a youth. åÛåÏThere has to be some balance here. This is our chance.åÛå         This year with DetroitåÛåªs financial troubles becoming desperately apparent Gov. Rick Snyder a Republican called on Mr. Orr who had worked on ChrysleråÛåªs bankruptcy and at  the Resolution Trust Corporation  to be sent as an emergency manager with sweeping powers.         At first Mr. Orr said he resisted. The salary $275000 a year from the state would be a pay cut. His wife who is a physician would be caring for their two children 6 and 7 at home in Chevy Chase Md. when he was in Detroit. And the circumstances were certain to be volatile in a city that was hardly asking for an outsider to step in. Ultimately Mr. Orr said he became convinced that it was a call to action.         In the nearly nine months since Mr. Orr has been continually on the move meeting with community groups issuing reports filing for bankruptcy firing and hiring people at City Hall.         His supporters say he is astute and charming but also direct. åÛåÏThe thing is his stock is as high today as it was when he walked in the dooråÛå said Sandy K. Baruah the president of the Detroit Regional Chamber.         But he has also been a target during protests. Detroiters groaned at the attitude they perceived in  a comment he made  to The Wall Street Journal: åÛåÏFor a long time the city was dumb lazy happy and rich.åÛå Mr. Orr has said it was in no way meant as an insult against contemporary Detroiters but an observation about circumstances 100 years ago.         And DetroitåÛåªs mayor Dave Bing who is leaving office at the end of the year has said Mr. Orr arrived in the municipal building (where Mr. Orr has a second office not far from Mr. BingåÛåªs) with a slew of outside consultants and personnel changes but precious little expertise in running a city.         åÛåÏKevyn has tried to take on way too muchåÛå Mr. Bing said in an interview adding that he doubted speculation that the  incoming mayor Mike Duggan  might get some larger role. åÛåÏWhoever the mayor is and the City Council are they wonåÛåªt have a say in how to run the city.åÛå         Some critics bristle at the suggestion that Mr. Orr åÛåÓ rather than Governor Snyder and the Republican majority in the state capital Lansing åÛåÓ is running this city where tensions over race and class have long simmered. Mr. Orr and Governor Snyder both attended law school in overlapping years at the University of Michigan where Mr. Orr had also gotten his undergraduate degree. The two meet and talk regularly the governoråÛåªs spokeswoman said. Mr. Orr stays in a condominium at the Westin Book Cadillac  that has been paid for by a tax-exempt fund  the governor created.         åÛåÏThey pull the levers and he reads the script at the press conferencesåÛå said the Rev. Charles Williams II of the  National Action Network . åÛåÏIn our community we call that window dressing.åÛå         Mr. Orr has heard it all before; mainly he dismisses it. He says that he is a Democrat and has never voted for a Republican and that Governor Snyder was a åÛåÏfleeting acquaintanceåÛå in law school.         And however his life may appear to others åÛåÓ the classic suits and the state police security detail åÛåÓ Mr. Orr says simply that he sees himself as a part of Detroit. In the cityåÛåªs churches he says he smells the Florida church his grandfather led the old Bibles and the organs. Both his grandmothers had studied to the eighth grade and worked as maids.         åÛåÏWhen I say åÛå÷IåÛåªm themåÛåªÌâåÊåÛå Mr. Orr said of Detroiters åÛåÏI want people to understand donåÛåªt look at who I am now. I have by no means forgotten.åÛå         On the most contentious issues Mr. Orr has held hard lines. He refuses to promise that works at the  Detroit Institute of Arts  will go untouched in bankruptcy. He says city pensions for retirees are unaffordable as they are now despite state constitutional protections.         Not long ago Mr. OrråÛåªs mother a retired school administrator from Florida who receives a pension met a Detroit retiree at a conference. åÛåÏThey were crying togetheråÛå Mr. Orr said. åÛåÏShe said åÛå÷Kevyn do you have to do this?åÛåªÌâåÊåÛå         åÛåÏIf we donåÛåªt do something in the next 10 or 12 yearsåÛå Mr. Orr said åÛåÏthere wonåÛåªt be pensions for the 30- 40- and 50-year olds. Is that fair?åÛå         Mr. Orr has cleared one of his biggest hurdles: getting approval for bankruptcy. Though he is more accustomed to asking questions in courtrooms he spent days testifying about DetroitåÛåªs dismal conditions providing a pivotal basis for the judgeåÛåªs determination.         But the trial also shed light on his tactics in  filing for bankruptcy . Judge Steven W. Rhodes found that Mr. Orr and his team had not bargained in good faith before heading to court (though the judge also found that bargaining would have been impracticable given the some 100000 creditors). In one testy exchange the judge asked Mr. Orr about a statement he had made at a town-hall-style meeting in June that pensions were åÛåÏsacrosanct.åÛå         åÛåÏWhat would you say to that retiree now?åÛå the judge asked.         åÛåÏI would say his rights are subject to the supremacy clause in the U.S. ConstitutionåÛå Mr. Orr said.         åÛåÏThatåÛåªs a little bit different than sacrosanct isnåÛåªt it?åÛå         By next October åÛåÓ when under state law DetroitåÛåªs elected leaders can remove Mr. Orr åÛåÓ he hopes the city will have emerged from court with eased debts and reinvestment in services from streetlights to garbage pickup.         It is a tall order. He expects a new agency to put thousands of streetlights on key roads and near bus stops. He wants a remade police department åÛåÓ he has already hired a new chief åÛåÓ to drive down crime. He wants a åÛåÏsuperchargedåÛå effort to remove tens of thousands of abandoned buildings.         åÛåÏIn three years hopefully the blight is goneåÛå Mr. Orr said. åÛåÏThat would be my dream.åÛå

GENEVA åÛåÓ The United Nations' first relief airlift to Syria from Iraq will deliver food and winter supplies to the mostly Kurdish northeast over the next 10 days with the permission of both governments U.N. aid agencies said on Tuesday.         The airbridge using Ilyushin-76 commercial cargo planes flying to Hassakeh from Arbil in northern Iraq will begin on Thursday. Up to 12 flights are scheduled through Sunday said Amin Awad director of the U.N. refugee agency's Middle East and North Africa Bureau.         Elisabeth Byrs a spokeswoman for the U.N.'s World Food Programme (WFP) later said that it also planned 10 rotations over the next 10 days in an operation aimed at feeding more than 30000 people for a month. Its first flight would carry 40 metric tons of food including wheat flour pasta oil sugar salt rice canned beans and bulgur wheat she said.         U.N. agencies have ferried limited aid supplies into Syria from Iraq and Lebanon but not via Turkey because of objections from President Bashar al-Assad's government.         "This is the first time aid goes through Iraq" Awad told Reuters in an interview in Geneva.         Syria gave permission about two weeks ago for the cross-border U.N. operation from Iraq into Syrian Kurdish areas of Hassakeh province which had initially envisaged truck convoys via the Yarubiya border crossing a cheaper option he said.         "As the situation was very complicated negotiating with many factions we shifted to an airlift" Awad said noting that one main Kurdish group in the area was pro-Syrian government and the other pro-Turkish.         The previously unannounced joint UNHCR-WFP operation had been long planned by land a Western diplomat said. "They had trucks and were ready to move a week ago. It was supposed to be over this past weekend but it didn't happen" he told Reuters.         The cities of Hassakeh and Qamishli are to receive food and relief items as a harsh winter sets in Awad said.         "OUT OF REACH FOR A LONG TIME"         The total cargo of 285 metric tons to be brought in by the U.N. refugee agency will also include blankets kitchen sets plastic tarpaulins for shelter sleeping mats and jerry cans UNHCR spokesman Dan McNorton said.         "The number of vulnerable people in Hassakeh is estimated at 50000-60000 but we are still doing assessments. Hassakeh has been out of reach for a long time" Awad said.         Awad said the United Nations was still "lining up airlines that are willing to fly into that part of the country".         Well over 100000 people have been killed in the conflict in Syria which began with peaceful protests against Assad in March 2011. The UNHCR says about 6.5 million people have fled their homes within Syria and 2.3 million sought refuge abroad.         "Winter is here. This is one of the harshest winters according to any forecast that you may get hold of probably in the last 100 years" Awad told a news briefing.         Iraq's envoy to the U.N. Nickolay Mladenov tweeted:         "As @UNiraq and #Iraq agree humanitarian corridor to #Syria I call on all to allow for the resupply to take place in an unobstructed manner."         (Reporting by Stephanie Nebehay additional reporting by Sylvia Westall in Baghdad; Editing by Ralph Boulton)

BRUSSELS åÛåÓ European Union finance ministers are unlikely to reach a final agreement on Tuesday on how to close down failing euro zone banks and how to finance that European Central Bank Executive Board member Joerg Asmussen said.         "We would not expect to reach a final agreement today" he told reporters on entering the meeting.         "I have already pencilled in another Ecofin before the EU summit" he said referring to the meeting of EU leaders schedule for Dec 19-20.         (Reporting By Jan Strupczewski; editing by Barbara Lewis)

Men in frocks a tradition as ancient as  Aeschylus  has been revived time and again onstage in clubs and sometimes in the broadest strokes at the suburban megaplex. Wherever she appears though the sight of a burly man compressed in a curve-hugging mermaid gown rarely fails to elicit in audiences a queasy mix of empathy and raucous laughter.         It does even now as a new crop of cross-dressing Broadway and Hollywood stars injects this venerable genre with currency and a jolt of fresh vitality.         While the catalog of indelible performances then and now is far too extensive to cite in a breath (much less memorialize in a few column inches) the vivid handful enshrined in peopleåÛåªs consciousness surely has to include that of  Tony Curtis  tricked out as a demure and surprisingly pretty chanteuse fleeing mobsters an equally dainty  Jack Lemmon  at his side in the 1959  Billy Wilder  hit  åÛåÏSome Like It Hot.åÛå  At the other extreme is Divine in the 1972 landmark John Waters film åÛåÏPink FlamingosåÛå her lavish contours encased in scarlet her only accessories Mephistophelian eyebrows chandelier earrings åÛåÓ and a gun.         Such impersonations can be broken down roughly into three subgroups: the winsome sylph the brazen diva (all whiskey contralto and vulcanized curves) and the genteel matron.         This last a bosomy archetype was persuasively embodied by  Dustin Hoffman  as the coyly bespectacled title character in  åÛåÏTootsieåÛå  (1982) and by the cardigan-shrouded  Robin Williams  a.k.a.  Mrs. Euphegenia Doubtfire  in 1993. To say nothing of Madea the portly invention of a cross-dressing Tyler Perry who made her film debut in  åÛåÏDiary of a Mad Black WomanåÛå  (2005) trussed in a fat suit and toting a massive poitrine. (She returns in a sequel next month.)         The pantheon of divas varies from those lustily portrayed by  Harvey Fierstein  the doyenne of drag who in April will bring to Broadway åÛåÏCasa ValentinaåÛå about a 1960s vacation retreat where straight men dress as women; to Gene Hackman wearing a candy-floss wig and sprouting chest hair in the 1996 movie  åÛåÏThe BirdcageåÛå ; to John Cameron Mitchell a stringier type tossing her yellow curls off Broadway and on the big screen in  åÛåÏHedwig and the Angry InchåÛå  her exposed rib cage giving her a touch of sylphlike vulnerability.         More often than not though the true sylph captures a poignancy rarely conveyed by her bombshell sisters. Consider Jaye Davidson Dil in  åÛåÏThe Crying GameåÛå  (1992) who seems achingly fragile even in a boyish crop and beefy cricket sweater.         Or  Jared Leto  the latest though hardly least impactful of cinematic sylphs as the wraithlike Rayon in the based-on-real-events movie  åÛåÏDallas Buyers Club.åÛå  (åÛåÏLean and beautiful he wears heels and furs wellåÛå  wrote  the New Yorker reviewer David Denby.)         Mr. LetoåÛåªs screen transformation åÛåÓ requiring shaved legs dollops of lip gloss and generous dustings of powder åÛåÓ has made him a contender  for an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor .         Though heåÛåªs not åÛåÏdoing dragåÛå by purist standards (his portrayal of a woman betrays no hint of parody)  Mark Rylance  is a doleful Olivia in the ShakespeareåÛåªs Globe revival of åÛåÏTwelfth NightåÛå on Broadway gliding Kabuki-style across the stage a corseted vision in a neck ruff and pearls.         If the sylph brings to her character a deeply intuited femininity it most often stops short of authentic womanliness.         But then miming reality well thatåÛåªs never really been the point.         Here is a fresh look at some of the best in the genre then and now:          Jared Leto   Who would have thought that Jared Leto could look so disarmingly pretty in pink? The blush-tinted robe in which he makes his entrance as Rayon the H.I.V.-positive transsexual in åÛåÏDallas Buyers ClubåÛå is a backdrop of sorts against which he shows off his precision-lined eyes Camille-like pallor and carmine tinted nails. At one point in the drama Mr. Leto a fashion chameleon trades his headwrap chicly knotted at the rear for a headful of curls and a succession of trailer-park-inspired frocks. Wearing one such pansy-patterned number he asks fretfully: åÛåÏDo you like this dress? Because I think the neckline is a little plunging.åÛå That may be. But cut to the sternum it somehow brings out his wispy femininity.          Mark Rylance   Mark Rylance as Countess Olivia in the current Broadway production of åÛåÏTwelfth NightåÛå isnåÛåªt delivering a drag performance not in the strictest terms (he plays the lady straight; you accept her as a woman). But trussed in a jet-colored heavily boned gown and starchy ruff he exudes a kind of regal glamour his rigorously elegant costume likely to inspire a flurry of look-alikes on the runways next year. His is an austere beauty for sure the sort that deserves its own frame. And itåÛåªs only enhanced by a face thickly dusted in arsenic-white powder and a gliding gait åÛåÓ a walk borrowed equally it seems from Kabuki and the Ice Capades.          Jaye Davidson   åÛåÏA bit heavy on the powder isnåÛåªt she?åÛå a catty visitor says of Dil the transgender love interest in " The Crying Game.åÛå To which Dil ( Jaye Davidson) retorts without missing a beat åÛåÏA girl has to have a bit of glamour.åÛå Glamour is a quality Dil projects emphatically from her voice a steamy tenor and gazellelike neck to a pair of stems that seem born to stride the most rarefied catwalks. Mauve-tinted eye shadow and a gender-bending wardrobe of glittery dresses frayed denim shorts and a racy vinyl trench do their part as well in supplying her uncanny allure. Among the filmåÛåªs ironies is that even in an outsize cricket sweater Dil seems more authentically feminine than Jude her vixenish archnemesis an actual woman who could pass for a travesty in a Mugler suit and bangs.          Patrick Swayze   There is something radiant and palpably convincing in the sight of Patrick Swayze pruning his brows and dabbing on foundation in the 1995 road-trip comedy " To Wong Foo Thanks for Everything! Julie Newmar.åÛå Watching his drag queen Vida Boheme ease his ripped frame into a Merry Widow would have been less of a hoot had Mr. Swayze not been better known to his fans as a granite-jawed heartthrob and action hero. Decadent in aubergine primly attractive in white Vida projects a brew of sass and class that any Charleston-bred debutante might envy. Mr. Swayze once said that he felt ravishing as Vida confiding in an interview that the final day of filming left him feeling a tad mournful. åÛåÏI thoughtåÛå he recalled wistfully åÛåÏthis is the last time that I get to be pretty.åÛå          Billy Porter

THIS was the week when liberals decided that it was safe to feel optimistic about Obamacare again.         Not mind you because the websiteåÛåªs flaws have all been wiped away or because the pace of enrollment is where the White House wanted it to be or because the political backlash over plan cancellations has disappeared. The site may be better the  enrollment pace higher  the backlash no longer front-page news åÛåÓ but the lawåÛåªs rollout is by any reasonable definition still a dreadful mess.         But a worst-case scenario in which the website remained unusable well into the new year seems to have been averted and with it the danger that insurers or Congressional Democrats would begin to bail on Obamacare entirely.         And liberals have apparently decided that just  getting things moving  in the  right direction  makes  all the difference . Sure problems persist crucial errors remain and confusion probably looms for some customers and insurers in January when policies are supposed to take effect. But  errors  can be fixed money  sluiced around  more temporary changes made. The important thing is there will be no immediate political unraveling ... which means that enrollment will keep rising ... which means that by 2016 Obamacare will be a locked-in impossible-to-repeal feature of the American landscape.         This holds true liberals have begun telling themselves even if the lawåÛåªs disruptions cost Democrats dearly in the 2014 midterms. Because a working website will give the White House åÛåÏthree full years to create millions and perhaps tens of millions of winners who are getting insurance or protectionåÛå The Washington PoståÛåªs Ezra Klein wrote last week Democrats can åÛåÏlose on the politics in the midterm election even as they win on the policy in the long term.åÛå         The entrenchment hypothesis is  plausible . But it elides one crucial problem: the extent to which the successful implementation of Obamacare actuallyÌâåÊ depends ÌâåÊon the lawåÛåªs political standing.ÌâåÊ         ThatåÛåªs because the law can work only if people who donåÛåªt necessarily benefit immediately from its provisions decide to participate anyway. If they respond to higher premiums by either staying out or dropping out then Obamacare will be permanently unstable: the dollar figures both for insurers and the government simply wonåÛåªt add up.         The participation of the young and healthy is supposed to be required of course by the individual mandate. But the mandateåÛåªs penalty is relatively modest and its enforcement mechanisms relatively weak which means its power ultimately depends more on civic duty than on immediate self-interest.         The lawåÛåªs advocates have explicitly acknowledged this point. Explaining the case for the mandate last month The AtlanticåÛåªs Matt OåÛåªBrien allowed that åÛåÏ a rational self-maximizer åÛå might decide to pay the fine instead of buying costly coverage. But åÛåÏreal peopleåÛå he argued åÛåÏarenåÛåªt rational self-maximizers ... We donåÛåªt like to feel like weåÛåªre doing the wrong thing. We like to follow the rules instead. Feel like weåÛåªre a good person.åÛå         The experience of Mitt RomneyåÛåªs Massachusetts OåÛåªBrien concluded shows how this works: enrollment in Romneycare spiked when the mandate kicked in and it spiked for healthy people åÛåÓ presumably because they accepted the åÛåÏpositive responsibilityåÛå of the mandate and bought health insurance because itåÛåªs what they were åÛåÏsupposed to do.åÛå         But this example does not necessarily bode well for ObamacareåÛåªs unfolding. The Massachusetts law was a bipartisan bill passed in a wealthy homogeneous state with a pervasive left-liberal ethos. The national health care law aspires to create the same sense of åÛåÏpositive responsibilityåÛå in a much more polarized fragmented socioeconomically diverse and libertarian-minded society roughly half of which opposes the law outright.         This was always going to be a lift even without technological problems and åÛåÏif you like your plan you can keep your planåÛå disillusionment. Now itåÛåªs much much heavier.         Consider the  findings  of a new poll from HarvardåÛåªs Institute of Politics. Among the traditionally pro-Obama millennial generation the core group that the White House needs to åÛåÏfollow the rulesåÛå and buy a policy the presidentåÛåªs approval ratings have dropped to 41 percent and support for Obamacare has also plunged: 56 percent of 18- to 29-year-olds disapprove of the law a majority say it will increase costs and just 18 percent say it will improve their care. Meanwhile a new National Journal  survey  finds that a majority of millennials expect the law to be repealed outright.         Those are not numbers that suggest a population thatåÛåªs poised to fall in line do its civic duty and feel warm and fuzzy in the process. Rather they suggest that the political emotions stirred up by the rollout åÛåÓ frustration disillusionment anger åÛåÓ could have substantial consequences for sign-up rates as well.         åÛåÏIf thereåÛåªs one thing we know how to doåÛå  said a White House official  last spring projecting optimism about Obamacare enrollment åÛåÏitåÛåªs reach young people.åÛå         Now though the fate of their policy may depend on not only reaching them but reconverting them as well.

After living in what must have seemed like every neighborhood in three boroughs åÛåÓ Coney Island the South Bronx East Flatbush Spanish Harlem (as it was then called) the Lower East Side åÛåÓ my motheråÛåªs parents in their oldish age settled in Astoria which is where I spent almost all the Thanksgivings of my childhood.         With the odd exception of 1963 when the mood was awful but the weather glorious  Thanksgiving  was always (in my memory) gray and blustery. My grandmotheråÛåªs kitchen was steamy. She roasted she sautÌÄå©ed she fried she boiled and she kvetched. She produced almost solo the traditionally ridiculous abundance of food including my favorite the potato nik a huge latke fried in chicken fat until really brown and as crisp as perfectly done shoestring fries. I still make this and so can you.         You can also make åÛåÓ perhaps not Thursday but surely beginning on Friday with Wylie DufresneåÛåªs leftover turkey hash åÛåÓ this lovely variety of dishes produced by a bevy of my favorite chefs including April Bloomfield Danny Bowien Claudia Fleming and AndrÌÄå© Soltner. Your Thanksgiving may be happier in anticipation of cooking these; I hope so.          Mark BittmanåÛåªs Potato Nik    Wylie DufresneåÛåªs Turkey Hash    Danny BowienåÛåªs Thanksgiving Pastrami     Claudia FlemingåÛåªs Apple Crumb Crostata    AndrÌÄå© SoltneråÛåªs Pumpkin Soup    April BloomfieldåÛåªs Clam Chowder

LONDON ‰ÛÒ The  Royal Bank of Scotland  said Tuesday that Nathan Bostock resigned as chief financial officer after less than three months in the job. Mr. Bostock will join Banco Santander‰Ûªs British unit as deputy chief executive and chief risk officer a spokesman for Santander UK said. Mr. Bostock was promoted to finance chief at R.B.S. at the beginning of October after Ross McEwan took over as chief executive. In a brief statement R.B.S. said Mr. Bostock had ‰ÛÏinformed the board of his intention to resign from his role as group finance director‰Û and that ‰ÛÏarrangements for his successor will be announced in due course.‰Û The bank which is majority-owned by the government after a 2008 bailout did not give a reason for the resignation but added that Mr. Bostock would remain at the bank to help with an orderly handover of his responsibilities. Mr. Bostock‰Ûªs resignation is the latest setback for Mr. McEwan and R.B.S. which apologized last week after a systems crash left millions of its customers unable to pay with their debit or credit cards. A week earlier the bank said it would hire the law firm Clifford Chance to review its lending practices after criticism from two separate reports.   Before becoming finance chief Mr. Bostock was R.B.S.‰Ûªs head of risk and restructuring. Most recently Mr. Bostock worked on the creation of a so-called internal bad bank that would group all of R.B.S.‰Ûªs less liquid and toxic assets together. The step followed a government review into whether R.B.S. should be split up to aid its recovery.
